articles.headline: Central Bank Raises Rates in Japan
articles.snippet: The Bank of Japan raised interest rates for the first time in six years in an important test of its ability to manage the economy.
articles.abstract: The Bank of Japan raised interest rates for the first time in six years in an important test of its ability to manage the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Friday July 14 — Japan’s central bank raised interest rates on Friday for the first time in six years, a widely watched move that economists called an important test of the embattled bank’s ability to manage the rebounding Japanese economy.

articles.headline: Should Faulty Old Audits Be Forgotten?
articles.snippet: When audits fail and scandals erupt, it sometimes turns out that the failure started small and grew as an error was repeated.
articles.abstract: When audits fail and scandals erupt, it sometimes turns out that the failure started small and grew as an error was repeated.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN audits fail and scandals erupt, it sometimes turns out that the audit failure started small with the auditor overlooking, or even accepting, something that was not really all that important, even if it was not good accounting.

articles.headline: On Wall Street, a Question of Bias
articles.snippet: Wall Street has long been seen as an exclusive club, and a discrimination suit against Merrill Lynch underscores that it is still struggling to overcome that reputation.
articles.abstract: Wall Street has long been seen as an exclusive club, and a discrimination suit against Merrill Lynch underscores that it is still struggling to overcome that reputation.
articles.lead_paragraph: For almost seven years, Glenn D. Capel has been a financial adviser in a busy Merrill Lynch office in Greensboro, N.C., but he says he has never felt more isolated.

articles.headline: Israel Blockades Lebanon; Wide Strikes by Hezbollah
articles.snippet: Early on Friday, Israeli airstrikes hit Hezbollah offices in south Beirut and the main highway between the Lebanese capital and Damascus, Syria.
articles.abstract: Early on Friday, Israeli airstrikes hit Hezbollah offices in south Beirut and the main highway between the Lebanese capital and Damascus, Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, July 14 — Israel imposed a full naval blockade on Lebanon on Thursday and put Beirut’s international airport out of commission, and the militant group Hezbollah loosed a hail of rockets and mortar shells that killed two Israelis and sent thousands into bomb shelters.
articles.byline: By Hassan M. Fattah and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Oil Prices Put Pressure on Shares
articles.snippet: Prices are expected to continue to surge after reaching a new high Thursday, causing stocks to fall amid growing uncertainty in the Middle East.
articles.abstract: Prices are expected to continue to surge after reaching a new high Thursday, causing stocks to fall amid growing uncertainty in the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks fell sharply yesterday for a second day as oil prices surged to a new high amid growing turmoil in the Middle East.

articles.headline: Accused G.I. Was Troubled Long Before Iraq
articles.snippet: A former Army private accused of rape and murder was a high school dropout with a minor criminal record before he enlisted in a soldier-strapped Army.
articles.abstract: A former Army private accused of rape and murder was a high school dropout with a minor criminal record before he enlisted in a soldier-strapped Army.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the last day of January 2005, Steven D. Green, the former Army private accused of raping a 14-year-old Iraqi girl and murdering her family, sat in a Texas jail on alcohol-possession charges, an unemployed 19-year-old high school dropout who had just racked up his third misdemeanor conviction.
articles.byline: By Jim Dwyer and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: A Big Vision, Only if G.M. Is Willing
articles.snippet: Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Renault and Nissan, hopes to reach a global alliance with General Motors, quickly.
articles.abstract: Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Renault and Nissan, hopes to reach a global alliance with General Motors, quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Renault and Nissan, laid out the parameters yesterday for the global alliance he hopes to reach with General Motors: he wants it to be big, he would like it to happen fast, and he emphasizes it must be friendly.

articles.headline: Videos, Doubts, and a Backlash in Mexico Vote
articles.snippet: Some of Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s  supporters say his arguments to discredit the official vote count are flawed.
articles.abstract: Some of Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s  supporters say his arguments to discredit the official vote count are flawed.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY, July 13 — To an untrained eye, the scenes captured on video certainly looked like Mexico’s bad old days when votes were stolen instead of won. There was a man inside a polling station stuffing one vote after another into a ballot box.
articles.byline: By Ginger Thompson and James C. McKinley Jr

articles.headline: Music Deal Is Rejected in Europe
articles.snippet: Following a rare court decision, Sony and Bertelsmann must submit to a new review of the music venture, Sony-BMG Music Entertainment.
articles.abstract: Following a rare court decision, Sony and Bertelsmann must submit to a new review of the music venture, Sony-BMG Music Entertainment.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS, July 13  In a rare move, a European court invalidated regulators’ approval of the 2004 merger of the music divisions of Sony and Bertelsmann, a ruling that cast doubt on consolidation plans in the recording industry as well as regulators’ ability to examine mergers.
articles.byline: By Paul Meller and Jeff Leeds

articles.headline: Accused G.I. Was Troubled Long Before Iraq
articles.snippet: On the last day of January 2005, Steven D. Green, the former Army private accused of raping a 14-year-old Iraqi girl and murdering her family, sat in a Texas jail on alcohol-possession charges, an unemployed 19-year-old high school dropout who had...
articles.abstract: On the last day of January 2005, Steven D. Green, the former Army private accused of raping a 14-year-old Iraqi girl and murdering her family, sat in a Texas jail on alcohol-possession charges, an unemployed 19-year-old high school dropout who had just racked up his third misdemeanor conviction.      Days later, Mr. Green enlisted in a soldier-strapped Army, and was later assigned to a star-crossed unit to serve on an especially murderous patch of earth.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the last day of January 2005, Steven D. Green, the former Army private accused of raping a 14-year-old Iraqi girl and murdering her family, sat in a Texas jail on alcohol-possession charges, an unemployed 19-year-old high school dropout who had just racked up his third misdemeanor conviction.
articles.byline: By Jim Dwyer and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: Old Wounds Reopen in Lebanon
articles.snippet: Members of the Lebanese Red Cross, above, took bodies to a morgue in Tyre, south of Beirut. Lebanon found itself virtually cut off from the world as the main highway linking Beirut and Damascus, Syria, was bombed. Israeli warships patrolled the sh...
articles.abstract: Members of the Lebanese Red Cross, above, took bodies to a morgue in Tyre, south of Beirut. Lebanon found itself virtually cut off from the world as the main highway linking Beirut and Damascus, Syria, was bombed. Israeli warships patrolled the shores.      Many Lebanese began re-enacting rituals learned during 15 years of civil war. They hoarded canned foods, spare batteries and candles. Some prepared bomb shelters and others hunkered down for a protracted siege.       BY HASSAN M. FATTAH, PAGE A11
articles.lead_paragraph: Members of the Lebanese Red Cross, above, took bodies to a morgue in Tyre, south of Beirut. Lebanon found itself virtually cut off from the world as the main highway linking Beirut and Damascus, Syria, was bombed. Israeli warships patrolled the shores.

articles.headline: A Shift of Balance for Bush
articles.snippet: The president has been forced to negotiate with Congress over his powers in what he calls ''a new kind of war.'' News analysis, Page A15.
articles.abstract: The president has been forced to negotiate with Congress over his powers in what he calls ''a new kind of war.'' News analysis, Page A15.
articles.lead_paragraph: The president has been forced to negotiate with Congress over his powers in what he calls "a new kind of war." News analysis, Page A15.

articles.headline: Overnight, a Boost for Hard-Liners
articles.snippet: In crossing the border and seizing Israeli soldiers, the militant group Hezbollah has also seized the initiative from Lebanese factions that have struggled with how to rein in the group.     But the political ripples from that raid and an earlier ...
articles.abstract: In crossing the border and seizing Israeli soldiers, the militant group Hezbollah has also seized the initiative from Lebanese factions that have struggled with how to rein in the group.     But the political ripples from that raid and an earlier attack by Gazan militants have spread far beyond Lebanon's borders. The widening Arab-Israeli conflict has crowded out moderate voices throughout the Middle East. Again, militant emotion and anger are setting the agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: In crossing the border and seizing Israeli soldiers, the militant group Hezbollah has also seized the initiative from Lebanese factions that have struggled with how to rein in the group.

articles.headline: Should Faulty Old Audits Be Forgotten?
articles.snippet: WHEN audits fail and scandals erupt, it sometimes turns out that the audit failure started small with the auditor overlooking, or even accepting, something that was not really all that important, even if it was not good accounting.      But as the...
articles.abstract: WHEN audits fail and scandals erupt, it sometimes turns out that the audit failure started small with the auditor overlooking, or even accepting, something that was not really all that important, even if it was not good accounting.      But as the error is repeated year after year, it grows, as the Securities and Exchange Commission pointed out in 2001, when it barred some partners of Arthur Andersen from continuing to audit public companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN audits fail and scandals erupt, it sometimes turns out that the audit failure started small with the auditor overlooking, or even accepting, something that was not really all that important, even if it was not good accounting.

articles.headline: Bush Would Let Secret Court Sift Wiretap Process
articles.snippet: After months of resistance, the White House agreed Thursday to allow a secret intelligence court to review the legality of the National Security Agency's program to conduct wiretaps without warrants on Americans suspected of having ties to terrori...
articles.abstract: After months of resistance, the White House agreed Thursday to allow a secret intelligence court to review the legality of the National Security Agency's program to conduct wiretaps without warrants on Americans suspected of having ties to terrorists.      If approved by Congress, the deal would put the court, the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, in the unusual position of deciding whether the wiretapping program is a legitimate use of the president's power to fight terrorism. The aim of the plan, Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales told reporters, would be to ''test the constitutionality'' of the program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 13 - After months of resistance, the White House agreed Thursday to allow a secret intelligence court to review the legality of the National Security Agency's program to conduct wiretaps without warrants on Americans suspected of having ties to terrorists.

articles.headline: Hezbollah Rains Rockets on Israel
articles.snippet: A child, above, was rushed into the main hospital in the northern Israeli town of Nahariya after the militant group Hezbollah fired a rocket barrage from southern Lebanon.      In the second day of heavy shooting across the border by Hezbollah, an...
articles.abstract: A child, above, was rushed into the main hospital in the northern Israeli town of Nahariya after the militant group Hezbollah fired a rocket barrage from southern Lebanon.      In the second day of heavy shooting across the border by Hezbollah, an apartment building in Nahariya took a direct hit and burst into flames. One woman was killed on the balcony of her apartment in another building. A man also died in the town of Safad. Hezbollah launched more than 120 rockets, the Israeli military said.       BY GREG MYRE, PAGE A11
articles.lead_paragraph: A child, above, was rushed into the main hospital in the northern Israeli town of Nahariya after the militant group Hezbollah fired a rocket barrage from southern Lebanon.

articles.headline: On Wall Street, a Question of Bias
articles.snippet: For almost seven years, Glenn D. Capel has been a financial adviser in a busy Merrill Lynch office in Greensboro, N.C., but he says he has never felt more isolated.     For most of his time with Merrill, Mr. Capel said, he has been the only black ...
articles.abstract: For almost seven years, Glenn D. Capel has been a financial adviser in a busy Merrill Lynch office in Greensboro, N.C., but he says he has never felt more isolated.     For most of his time with Merrill, Mr. Capel said, he has been the only black financial adviser among about 40 employed there, or indeed anywhere nearby. At the end of last year, he was one of only two in all of North and South Carolina, according to a racial-discrimination lawsuit against Merrill Lynch, the nation's largest brokerage firm, that is seeking class-action status in federal court in Chicago.
articles.lead_paragraph: For almost seven years, Glenn D. Capel has been a financial adviser in a busy Merrill Lynch office in Greensboro, N.C., but he says he has never felt more isolated.

articles.headline: A Big Vision, Only if G.M. Is Willing
articles.snippet: Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Renault and Nissan, laid out the parameters yesterday for the global alliance he hopes to reach with General Motors: he wants it to be big, he would like it to happen fast, and he emphasizes it must be friendly...
articles.abstract: Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Renault and Nissan, laid out the parameters yesterday for the global alliance he hopes to reach with General Motors: he wants it to be big, he would like it to happen fast, and he emphasizes it must be friendly.     Mr. Ghosn is scheduled to meet today with his G.M. counterpart, Rick Wagoner, in Detroit. The impetus for the meeting came from G.M.'s biggest shareholder, Kirk Kerkorian, who suggested two weeks ago that the three companies consider working together.
articles.lead_paragraph: Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive of Renault and Nissan, laid out the parameters yesterday for the global alliance he hopes to reach with General Motors: he wants it to be big, he would like it to happen fast, and he emphasizes it must be friendly.

articles.headline: Israel Blockades Lebanon; Wide Strikes by Hezbollah
articles.snippet: Israel imposed a full naval blockade on Lebanon on Thursday and put Beirut's international airport out of commission, and the militant group Hezbollah loosed a hail of rockets and mortar shells that killed two Israelis and sent thousands into bomb...
articles.abstract: Israel imposed a full naval blockade on Lebanon on Thursday and put Beirut's international airport out of commission, and the militant group Hezbollah loosed a hail of rockets and mortar shells that killed two Israelis and sent thousands into bomb shelters.     A day after cross-border raids by Hezbollah fighters brought Israeli troops into Lebanon in force for the first time in six years, Israel sent punishing airstrikes deeper into the country, hitting all three runways at Rafik Hariri International Airport, two Lebanese Army bases, and, early on Friday, Hezbollah offices in south Beirut and the main highway between the capital and Damascus, Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, July 14 - Israel imposed a full naval blockade on Lebanon on Thursday and put Beirut's international airport out of commission, and the militant group Hezbollah loosed a hail of rockets and mortar shells that killed two Israelis and sent thousands into bomb shelters.
articles.byline: By Hassan M. Fattah and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Central Bank Raises Rates in Japan
articles.snippet: Japan's central bank raised interest rates on Friday for the first time in six years, a widely watched move that economists called an important test of the embattled bank's ability to manage the rebounding Japanese economy.     After the end of a ...
articles.abstract: Japan's central bank raised interest rates on Friday for the first time in six years, a widely watched move that economists called an important test of the embattled bank's ability to manage the rebounding Japanese economy.     After the end of a two-day meeting, the Bank of Japan said in a statement that it had edged up its target for a benchmark overnight lending rate to 0.25 percent from zero, the clearest signal yet that the country's economy has pulled out of a decade-long slump and that its recovery was proving sustainable.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Friday July 14 - Japan's central bank raised interest rates on Friday for the first time in six years, a widely watched move that economists called an important test of the embattled bank's ability to manage the rebounding Japanese economy.

articles.headline: U.S. Alone on Israel's Side
articles.snippet: President Bush's qualified support for Israel's strikes on Lebanon put him on a potential collision course with his European allies on the eve of the annual Group of 8 summit meeting.     The European Union criticized what it called a ''disproport...
articles.abstract: President Bush's qualified support for Israel's strikes on Lebanon put him on a potential collision course with his European allies on the eve of the annual Group of 8 summit meeting.     The European Union criticized what it called a ''disproportionate use of force'' by Israel, and several governments singled out Israel's blockade tactics for condemnation. For its part, the Bush administration tempered its backing by warning that Israel should not destroy governmental resources or cause a refugee crisis.       BY JIM RUTENBERG, PAGE A10
articles.lead_paragraph: President Bush's qualified support for Israel's strikes on Lebanon put him on a potential collision course with his European allies on the eve of the annual Group of 8 summit meeting.

articles.headline: Oil Prices Put Pressure on Shares
articles.snippet: Stocks fell sharply yesterday for a second day as oil prices surged to a new high amid growing turmoil in the Middle East.     Investors, unnerved by news of an Israeli assault on Lebanon and other worries, pushed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock i...
articles.abstract: Stocks fell sharply yesterday for a second day as oil prices surged to a new high amid growing turmoil in the Middle East.     Investors, unnerved by news of an Israeli assault on Lebanon and other worries, pushed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index further down toward the low for the year it had reached last month. The benchmark index has now fallen 2.4 percent over the last two days, erasing its gain for the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks fell sharply yesterday for a second day as oil prices surged to a new high amid growing turmoil in the Middle East.
